title: Manchester City fan live streamed FA Cup match on Periscope - and 140,000 people watched it - Manchester Evening News
text:

The Premier League have promised a crackdown after a Manchester City fan live streamed one of the club’s games to more than 139,000 viewers - ten times the attendance at the ground. 
Josh Chambers, 23, was among the 4,000 Blues supporters who travelled to watch the Blues in their FA Cup fourth round tie at Crystal Palace last weekend. 
However thousands more were left searching online to try and find a way to see the match, which wasn’t televised. 
Among those were Josh’s dad, from Moss Side, and several of his family so he began filming it via the streaming app Periscope on his Iphone. Josh broadcast the game via the streaming app Periscope on his Iphone (Photo: PA) Read More Man City player ratings as Yaya Toure DOMINATES and David Silva shines 
And he was stunned as fans began to watch in their thousands including some from as far afield as America and South Korea. 
In total more than 139,000 watched the broadcast, ten times the attendance inside Selhurst Park in south London which was just 13,979. 
Local council worker Josh, who lives in Surrey, says he has had no complaints about the stream. 
However the Premier League have said they will take action against fans broadcasting their games. 
They employ a company who scours YouTube and social media sites to take down illegal streams and say this will include Periscope. 
Josh said: “It wasn’t on TV and I could see lots of people on Twitter trying to find a way to watch it. 
“That included my dad and some of my family so I thought I’d give it a go and see what happened. The game was not broadcast anywhere across the world - meaning fans from as far afield as America and South Korea tuned in to watch (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Read More Thousands expected to join anti-Donald Trump protest march in city centre 
“I obviously wasn’t expecting that many people to watch it but I know loads of City fans were really appreciative. 
“I had to keep swapping arms and even ask the guys behind me to hold the phone at one point.” 
He added: “No one has complained to me. 
“I can understand the Premier League want to protect their product. 
“But at the end of the day fans just want to watch their team and will always find a way to do it. 
“I’d definitely consider doing it again if it wasn’t on TV and there was no other way for people to watch it.” Like us on Facebook
